page.title: 19Ecology, Swainby & Potto
page.content: The area comprises open,{arable fields with some grazing land and a few {plantations.}Herbicides and pesticides are widely used; eggs of the ground- nesting lapwing and partridge are often ploughed under. Multi-specied hedges provide shelter for small birds eg, yellowhammer, long-tailed tit and wren.Against a background of intensive farming the{old rail line,}a relative- ly undisturbed area, is important for butterflies, birds and mammals. Kestrels, sparrowhawks and owls hunt over fields and along{road verges.} Numerous hares lure poachers. There are foxes, and an occasional otter. Deer stray from the{woods}to graze in pasture fields. Kingfishers, heron, dippers and waterfowl are seen in the slow-running{watercourses,}and trout in Swainby Beck.{Dutch Elm Disease}has eliminated elms from the area.
